subject: Welcome to Night Vale
header: After the slow week during Christmas, we have now tons of articles. Neil Bowers kicked off his CPAN Pull Request Challenge and a lot of people have joined.

entries.title: Djet
entries.author: kaare_rasmussen
entries.text: Djet is a Node Based Content Management System written in Perl. If you are confused like I was, don't worry. The 'node' in the name does not refer to Node.js, but more like the vertex in graph theory. I am not sure but I think the code behind PerlMonks is also based on the same idea, of everything is a node.

entries.title: A use for the scalar reverse (maybe)
entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: The 'reverse' function of perl can easily trick people as that too behaves differently in scalar and list context. In this article brian discusses some use cases when the scalar version might be useful.

entries.title: Makefile.PL as a modulino
entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: A modulino is a program that can act like a module, or a module that can be directly executed. While doing his CPAN Archeology brian turned his Makefile.PL into a modulino.

chapters.title: Perl Maven Pro
chapters.header: The Perl Maven Pro subscribers receive two new articles and screencasts every week. The last week these were the two screencasts:

entries.title: Moose constructor
entries.text: The beginning of a new series covering many advanced topic in Perl. This one starst the Object Oriented Programming with Moose section.

entries.title: Moose: Testing the constructor
entries.text: Using Moose to write classes in Perl is fun, but it is much more fun if we can even write unit-tests for our application.

entries.title: How to Go Wrong Testing HTML and Why It Took Me Forever to Fix It
entries.author: dave_rolsky
entries.text: Now with the CPAN Pull Request challenge going on, it is very interesting to read why a module author has delayed accepting a pull-request and how it lead to the creating of HTML::Differences that can find real differences between two HTML snippets.

entries.title: Test-Simple release plan
entries.author: chad_granum
entries.text: The Test-Simple distribution is the heart of all the testing in the Perl ecosystem. Changing it and releasing it to the CPAN can break the installation process of every Perl user around the worl. Helping Chad by testing it before he releases to everyone will surely make him happy.

entries.title: Perl Scripts
entries.text: A bunch of interesting Perl script examples

entries.title: RESTful APIs with Bedrock (part IV)
entries.author: rob_lauer
entries.text: Bedrock, or OpenBedrock is a web development framework that allows you to embed SQL code in HTML. To me it looks like something left here from the previous century, but I am impressed that Rob Lauer, the author keeps running the project and keeps writing blog-posts about it!

entries.title: New Dancer2 release en route to CPAN: 0.158000
entries.author: sawyerx
entries.text: Dancer2 is faster than Dancer and some parts of it got even faster with this release.

entries.title: Bring out yer distributions!
entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: Lots of people have signed up to the CPAN challenge Neil announced so he also needs the other part of the equation. Modules that need to be fixed.

entries.title: Pull request ideas
entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: If you particiapate in the CPAN challenge of Neil, then you might wonder what kind of improvements could be considered in a module. Don't worry, Neil has already prepared a list of ideas and if you have others, you can comment on his blog.

entries.title: Pull request etiquette
entries.author: neil_bowers
entries.text: Some ideas how to make sure the pull-request you send has a higher than average chance to get accepted.

entries.title: My CPAN Cleaning, Day 2457023.500000
entries.author: brian_d_foy
entries.text: As you upload newer and newer versions of your module to PAUSE and thus to CPAN, the old onese linger around taking up space and possibly confusing people. brian has this annual (or is that bi-annual?) ritual cleaning up his directory, removing the old versions. This time he goes further and makes sure modules he has on CPAN have their proper GitHub repository and other useful features.

entries.title: Downloading Welcome to Night Vale podcast episodes
entries.author: sawyer_x
entries.text: Welcome to Night Vale is a podcast from a fictional town somewhere in the south of the US. Sawyer wrote a script to download all the episodes.

entries.title: Improving Devel::Cover Grant Completed
entries.author: paul_johnson
entries.text: The full report of Paul Johnson on his grant and his work towards making Devel::Cover even more awesome than it was previously.

entries.title: Call For Grant Proposals (January 2015 Round)
entries.author: makoto_nozaki
entries.text: You can submit your grant proposal to The Perl Foundation till 14 January. The grants will be decided till 30th January.

entries.title: Act Voyager ---- long story
entries.text: Theo van Hoesel reports on his progress with the Act grant. Act is the application that handles the user accounts of most of the Perl-related conferences, workshops, and hackathons.

entries.title: Is 2015 going to be the year of Perl 6 ?
entries.author: gabor_szabo
entries.text: I have been on-and-off Perl 6 for quite some time, so after the news about Larry Wall talking about Perl 6 being production ready in 2015 I started to wonder if I should start wrting about Perl 6 again. Judging by the comments on Reddit there are quite a few people who prefer to spew hatered than to be constructive. We'll see.
